sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using Cramer's rule
message_1:
Find the solution to the following system of equations using Cramer's rule:

$$
\begin{cases}
2x + 3y = 7 \\
4x - y = 2
\end{cases}
$$
message_2:
To solve the given system of equations using Cramer's rule, we first need to find the determinant of the coefficient matrix, which we'll call D:

$$
D = \begin{vmatrix}
2 & 3 \\
4 & -1
\end{vmatrix}
= (2 \times -1) - (3 \times 4)
= -2 - 12
= -14
$$

Now, we'll find the determinant of the matrix obtained by replacing the first column of the coefficient matrix with the constants from the right side of the equations, which we'll call D_x:

$$
D_x = \begin{vmatrix}
7 & 3 \\
2 & -1
\end{vmatrix}
= (7 \times -1) - (3 \times 2)
= -7 - 6
= -13
$$

Similarly, we'll find the determinant of the matrix obtained by replacing the second column of the coefficient matrix with the constants from the right side of the equations, which we'll call D_y:

$$
D_y = \begin{vmatrix}
2 & 7 \\
4 & 2
\end{vmatrix}
= (2 \times 2) - (7 \times 4)
= 4 - 28
= -24
$$

Now, we can find the values of x and y using Cramer's rule:

$$
x = \frac{D_x}{D} = \frac{-13}{-14} = \frac{13}{14}
$$

$$
y = \frac{D_y}{D} = \frac{-24}{-14} = \frac{12}{7}
$$

So, the solution to the given system of equations is:

$$
x = \frac{13}{14}, \quad y = \frac{12}{7}
$$
